item.title: Admonitions
item.description: Admonitions are a technical writing tool to call out specific information and details in an article. This may be a note, general information, a tip, or a warning. The UNICEF Inventory supports multiple admonitions. These are used with shortcodes and work with any markup language (e.g. Markdown and AsciiDoc). One caveat: AsciiDoc is not supported inside an admonition. Admonition content only renders Markdown and HTML. See the examples below:

item.title: Author byline
item.description: Every article can be given an author byline. A byline is an attribution that appears prominently in the article. The byline can have two pieces of data: Author name Author email address The data is specified by adding front-matter to article. See the example below: 1author:Jane Doe2authorEmail:jane@example.com Figure 1. Byline in an article

item.title: Brand & identity
item.description: Table of Contents 1. Logo 2. Favicon 3. Default colors 4. Font The UNICEF Inventory theme includes several options to change text and visual appearance of the site. These options allow for greater customization of the Hugo theme for different brands and identities. This is done so that the UNICEF Inventory theme can be used in many different contexts as a knowledge management tool. 1. Logo A UNICEF Inventory site can also use a logo in the site navigation.

item.title: Code highlighting
Create a new Hugo site
item.description: This page documents how to create a new Hugo website using the UNICEF Inventory theme. You need to already understand the basics of Hugo. If you do not know about Hugo, review the Hugo documentation on getting started to learn more about the basics. Overview This guide assumes you will use GitHub to host the source content for your website and GitHub Pages to deploy the generated HTML built by Hugo.

item.title: Create a new UNICEF Toolkit
item.description: This guide provides supplementary information about creating a new UNICEF Toolkit with the UNICEF Inventory theme. Before reading this page, you should read “Create a new Hugo site” on how to set up a new Hugo website with the UNICEF Inventory theme. UNICEF GitHub The recommended way to create a new UNICEF Toolkit is to create a new GitHub repository on github.com/unicef. Creating a repository here allows you to leverage the unicef.

item.title: Page redirects
item.description: The UNICEF Inventory theme includes a feature that allows you to redirect the user to another website. Sometimes, a page hosted in your site is moved to another website. While Hugo allows you to create aliases that redirects one page to another in the same site, it is not possible to redirect a page to an external site. These page redirects solve that problem. To create a page redirect, define the layout type and redirectUrl in the page front-matter:

item.title: Tab tables
item.description: Tab tables are an advanced way of organizing complex information. It creates small, tabbed pages within an article. A user can click through them to view different information in each pane. This is especially useful when working with images to reduce vertical length. One caveat: Tab tables only render HTML. Markdown and AsciiDoc are not supported. See how they are used within an article below: Photo by Marisa Howenstine on Unsplash.
